Whenever you win, people will immediately assume you took a shortcut. 

Because the idea that you ran the entire race and won before they even got off the couch hurts their own ego so much, you cheating is the only reality their ego can stomach.
You always looks like an overnight success because they just found out about you.

How to stay poor:

Assume that anyone who makes more money than you is unethical.

When everyone leaves a party just as you get there, then you realize it‚Äôs your house and you need to clean it all by morning because important people are coming by tomorrow.

It‚Äôs 10 people‚Äôs worth of work. 

But it‚Äôs too late to call anyone and it has to get done tonight.

And it‚Äôs just you.

You stay up all night cleaning the house on your own from a mess you didn‚Äôt make. 

Mop. Dishes. Trash. So much trash. Bottles. Empties. Spills. Reorganize‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶It‚Äôs dawn and the house is starting to look presentable.

Just as the important people are supposed to show up, you get a text: ‚Äúsorry can‚Äôt make it. We‚Äôll have to reschedule.‚Äù

And there you are, alone, after spending all night cleaning up a mess you didn‚Äôt make for people who ended up not showing up. 

And as much as you‚Äôd like to sulk, or be tired, you‚Äôve got too much other stuff you have to do.

You‚Äôre two years in. It feels like there‚Äôs no end in sight and you‚Äôre not sure when it will get better. 

***
And rather than the social media glorification, that‚Äôs what entrepreneurship feels like 99% of the time.

A test of will, not intellect.

More people are terrified to lose what they have than to not achieve what they‚Äôre capable of.

When those fears flip, you become dangerous.
Entrepreneurship is a test of will, not intellect.

It‚Äôs rare that a definition stops me in my tracks‚Ä¶

This one by @DrKashey did. 

In response to someone who asked: 
‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to figure out who I really am‚Ä¶if I‚Äôm being authentically myself‚Äù

Answer: How you act when nothing can punish you.

That is who you really are.

A few years ago, I realized I wasn‚Äôt unhappy anymore.

The main change: living life noting ‚Äúgood days‚Äù and ‚Äúbad days‚Äù. 

Then, looking for the things I could control that happened on good days.  

Then, deliberately repeating them.

This lead me here: 
1) I eat the same stuff. This minimized bad food experiences and kept me in shape. Which always made me feel better than not being in shape. 

2) I lift weights with people I like. I noticed I always had good days if I worked out with people I liked.

3) I work on something I could see visible progress on (I write everyday). I noticed when I did that, I felt some larger accomplishment.

3.5) Later I realized if I did that activity with a friend, it made it even more enjoyable. Which is what has given birth to @DrKashey and my daily writing sessions.

4) I unwind with a nice view. I noticed when I had a dedicated place to sit quietly and read or reflect my days went better.

That‚Äôs about all I‚Äôve got that actually made me less unhappy. 

Simply paying attention to what happened on good days then trying to recreate it might‚Äôve been one of the most valuable things I‚Äôve done for myself. 

TLDR: I spend as much time as I can doing things I like with people I like and ignore as much of everything else as I can.

Ways to not feel stressed when ‚Äòbad‚Äô stuff happens:

1) Decide it isn‚Äôt bad. It just is. Remind yourself that you‚Äôre the one calling it bad. Most ‚Äòbad‚Äô things in the micro becomes ‚Äògood‚Äô things in the macro. 

2) See if you can remember something of equal importance from 20 years ago. If not, it probably won‚Äôt matter in the future. And it won‚Äôt matter then, it doesn‚Äôt matter now.

3) Imagine this bad thing happened every hour of everyday for the next two years. How would you feel on the 1,000th time of this happening? Probably like it‚Äôs just ‚Äòpart of life‚Äô. If it can feel that way then, it can feel that way now.

4) Remind yourself that if you zoom far enough out in space. Right now. That you can‚Äôt even see the earth. Reminds us that big problems are only big when compared to small things. Change what you compare your problems to, and they become small problems (or stop being one all together).

5) Remind yourself that right now. We remember entire civilizations as the ancient ‚ÄúX-ans‚Äù. Romans. Sumerians. Babylonians. And we may be the Ancient Americans to a future gen. Barely even remembering names of leaders. If we can‚Äôt remember their names, their problems certainly didn‚Äôt matter.

6) Jail. Bankruptcy. Ridicule. Whatever ‚Äúterrible‚Äù thing it is. Be grateful that you get to have this unique human experience. Most people may not ever experience it. But you can. Which gives you deeper insight no one can take from you. And that‚Äôs something to be grateful for. 

7) Remind yourself that the output of hard circumstances is strong character. After all, hard people don‚Äôt come from easy times. So we can‚Äôt wish for one without the other. In many cases, we‚Äôre getting our wish - to become the best version of ourselves. And this is just the way we become it.

These frames have helped me more than I can say. Hope they helps you.

To Ivante - the young man who stopped me at the grocery store working 2 jobs with a 1 year old who asked for advice on how to get ahead - I gave you a short answer because I was in a rush and it ate at me. So if you follow me here, maybe you‚Äôll read this.

What you‚Äôre going through is tough. 
Being so young and already having to support a child is not easy.
But you‚Äôll have the opportunity to become an amazing inspiration in a way I never could. Your success story will become your sermon.

That being said - onto the advice:

You‚Äôre gonna need to assume luck isn‚Äôt real. Or that it applies to everyone else but you.
Because the only way you‚Äôre gonna get out of your surroundings is by having something of value other people want.

And right now, the only thing you have is your time - with low skills - to trade.

Which is a hard game to play.

You‚Äôll have to trade a lot only to get a little.

So - you‚Äôre main objective is to have the time to learn a skill while providing for your family.

That means, in the short term, your family may have to suffer. Scratch that. Your family will suffer. But better now when they‚Äôre too young to remember than when they‚Äôre too old to forget.

Again, not forever. But for now. 

So these are the things you‚Äôre gonna have to do. And this isn‚Äôt ‚Äòdabble‚Äô stuff. 

This is - wake the f*ck up because if you don‚Äôt - you‚Äôre gonna blink and be 30 in the same spot, but worse. 

1) Cut all costs. And I mean ALL costs. You don‚Äôt eat out anymore. For anything. And if you‚Äôre hungry, you deal with it. If it‚Äôs not from a discount grocery store, you don‚Äôt buy it. Clothing - ha! What you‚Äôve got is everything you need for the next two years. Period. No exceptions. Reuse. Trade or go to goodwill. You go to work. You go home. And home - is ideally with your family, or worst case, with another family also trying to make it and save. And it‚Äôs gotta be as cheap as you possible.

2) Increase your income. You‚Äôre working two jobs. Your free time, spend applying to other jobs closer to what you want to do. Any at home phone sales job has starter roles that require zero experience that pay $40k/yr or more. Do that, and work your other job in between. If you can‚Äôt, drive Uber. If you don‚Äôt have a car, save up until you do.

3) The easiest thing to sell is someone else‚Äôs stuff. So start there. Then, learn how to buy stuff for cheap and flip it. The bigger the thing, the more you make. You go from flipping cards to furniture to homes. And the limit never really stops there.  

Final note: I could hear the stress in your voice when you were talking to me about your situation. It sounded like you didn‚Äôt know what to do. Sadness comes from a lack of options. It‚Äôs a feeling of hopelessness. But whenever you feel that, I want you to think ‚Äòthis is ignorance not sadness‚Äîit means I don‚Äôt know enough, and that, I can control.‚Äô

You asked to come work for free for me. 

But I have no need for low skilled labor. 

But I do have need for high skilled beasts. 

It‚Äôs why I make the books and the courses and the content, everywhere, for free.

So use those. Then get yourself a higher paying job. And everyday apply for higher paying ones (I recommend sales to start). 

Then once you get in there - for the love of god work until your fingers bleed because you have no other option. 

You have no luck. Nothing is gonna work out in your favor. You‚Äôre not gonna catch a break. 

You‚Äôre gonna have to make it happen. You‚Äôre gonna have to force it.

You‚Äôve gotta become undeniable. 

And the best news is - you can do that in less than a year. 

So that‚Äôs my advice: 

1) cut all your costs. Everything.
2) work more to make more. And apply to better jobs. Learn to sell. 
3) Start selling more expensive stuff then eventually stuff you own.

Two men set out to build a building.

One lays the foundation for a 10-story building and finishes the entire building in nine months. 

The other lays the foundation for a 100-story building and it takes him the entire nine months just to build the first few floors. 

The first ‚Äúbeing ahead‚Äù mocks the second for taking so long. He decides he wants to build his building into a 100-story building to prove how good of a builder he is. 

So he tries to add stories on top. He gets to 15-16 stories and then the foundation begins to crack. He starts reinforcing things. But no matter what, he feels he can‚Äôt put anymore on top. 

Over time, the second guy keeps building and passes the first man.

Two years later the second man completes his 100-story building despite barely having his foundation finished by the time the first man finishes his entire building.

The first man, goes to a mentor to ask his advice on growing his building taller.

The mentor tells him ‚Äúyou need to tear down this building or start another one new‚Äù

He says ‚Äúand waste all the time I spent building this one? Can‚Äôt I just add it on top if I just knew how?‚Äù

The mentor replies ‚Äúthere‚Äôs a lesson here: The fastest way to build a 10-story building isn‚Äôt the fastest way to a 100-story building. Your desire to grow fast ruined your ability to grow big.‚Äù

**
